p: The high ACE2 expression in the kidney and the presence of fragments of CoV in the patient blood and urine implicate COVID-19 in the renal system [33], [42]. Clinically, proteinuria in a large number of patients can be caused by virus-inducted cytopathic effect on podocytes, as podocyte injury induces heavy proteinuria [43]. Increased creatinine levels could also indicate indirect effects on renal function caused by the virus, such as hypoxia, shock, and rhabdomyolysis [4], [8]. Specifically, the effects of CoV-infected ACE2 can cause kidney damage through a heightened inflammatory response by depleting Ang 1–7 and Ang 1–9 levels. A systemic cytokine storm–induced inflammatory response can also cause multiple organ damage [42], [44]. It is unlikely that kidney injury arises from deposition of immune complex of viral antigen or virus-induced specific immunological effector mechanisms because glomeruli microscopy imaging has appeared normal in COVID-19 patients [38].
